author: jharrell@sbtinfo.com(Jeff Harrell)
title: LaSalle Grill and LaSalle Kitchen & Tavern give South Bend best of both fine-dining worlds
text:
by Jeff Harrell 
Downstairs is as fine as dining in South Bend gets. 
But LaSalle Grill founder and owner Mark McDonnell backed off a stringent dress code for the classy downtown restaurant that serves wood-fired steaks, a Faroe Isle salmon and that delectable hardwood-grilled double-cut pork chop on the bone cooked to perfection at the hands of a world-class staff headed by Executive Chef Tom Sheridan. 
“It’s still fine dining, and I just changed it in some of our training manuals to contemporary fine dining,” McDonnell says while seated in LaSalle Grill’s backroom bar on a recent Tuesday afternoon. 
So although your chances of getting served remain nil in LaSalle Grill’s elegant downstairs dining room if you show up in ratty jeans with holes and a T-shirt that defies obscenity standards, “Business casual is fine,” McDonnell says, “like a pair of nice jeans … You know, you have your $150 jeans, and I say that’s fine.” 
If the downstairs is about the LaSalle Grill’s signature filet mignon and a nice bottle of California pinot noir or South Australian Shiraz, the upstairs on the third floor at LaSalle Kitchen & Tavern is all about kicking back with beer, whiskey, burgers and live entertainment — T-shirts and jeans OK. 
Still, like its classy fine-dining relative downstairs, the LKT, as McDonnell calls his third-floor gastro bar, and its 30 craft beers on tap and in bottles plus 120 whiskeys, comes with its own chef. 
“People come in here and they’re like, ‘What, is it just bar food?’” LKT manager Dave O’Block, whose credentials include being a Level One cicerone, an official expert in craft beers equivalent to a sommelier’s wine expertise, says. “We have a chef-driven menu. They work in conjunction with the chefs downstairs, but we do have our own chefs up here as well.” 
Situated in the oldest commercial building in downtown South Bend — a historical landmark property built in 1868 that first housed the St. Joseph Hotel and later Sonneborn Sporting Shop that served as the area’s premier sporting goods store from 1934 to 1984 — McDonnell opened LaSalle Grill in 1991. 
When he bought the building seven years later, McDonnell’s first move was to partner his fine-dining restaurant on the first floor by opening the jazz venue Club LaSalle upstairs on the third floor. 
In 2013, he changed the club’s name and focus to LaSalle Kitchen & Tavern in a move intended to keep up with the mortality of a professional clientele that could afford the upscale prices of the LaSalle Grill and give the younger crowd a more relaxed eating and drinking atmosphere as well. 
The best of both fine-dining worlds under one roof turned out to be very prophetic considering the sale of the area’s other exclusive fine-dining restaurant, the Carriage House, earlier this year. 
“I wanted to create something that appealed more to the millennium generation because if you keep this going, it would be like a Carriage House,” McDonnell says. “And I said, I cannot let my customer base die. I wanted to start a new one where the brand is recognized. As they age and marry and get career jobs, maybe they’ll transfer down here (to LaSalle Grill) and go, ‘Well, I like both places, so I’ll go and eat and do my special occasions at LaSalle Grill, and hold my home-meal replacement up at LKT.” 
“We do get a different clientele,” O’Block adds. “I don’t want to say an age demographic, because it’s more of a foodies type … that want the smaller gastro pub type of feel.” 
Twenty-four years and counting, and now LaSalle Grill is the only restaurant in Indiana to receive the Four Diamond Award for 19 consecutive years. McDonnell also points out the Wine Spectator magazine Award of Excellence the restaurant has garnered for the past 10 years. 
But McDonnell is quick to insist that although the awards are nice, the customer comes first. Look no further than the LaSalle Grill’s hardwood-grilled double-cut pork chop, an impressive chunk of chop served on the bone that could melt in the mouths of at least two sharing diners. 
“We still do that double-cut pork chop,” McDonnell says. “We went to a thinner, what I thought was superior tasting and more bite-sized chop, but the people were going, ‘Where’s that big?’ … I want that big’.’ 
“They want the big,” he says, “so put ‘the big’ back on.”
